Prepared by Director of Programs, for board, Date 2025-11-02

End outcomes/impact we’re aiming for (3+ years):
- Adults 25–64 in Pike, Floyd, and Letcher Counties secure stable, digital-involved jobs with sustained wage gains.
- Households have reliable internet and devices that support work, health, and learning.
- Local employers fill in-demand roles with local talent, improving retention and productivity.
- A durable rural digital-skills pathway, embedded in partners, that reduces barriers for SNAP/TANF participants and underemployed jobseekers.

Logic Model Framework (24 months)

Inputs | Activities | Outputs | Short-term Outcomes (6–12 mo) | Intermediate Outcomes (1–3 yrs) | Long-term Outcomes/Impact (3+ yrs) | Indicators & Targets | Data Sources & Frequency | Responsible Role | Assumptions/External Factors | Equity Considerations
-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-
Team of 10; outreach budget; partner MOUs (SNAP/TANF offices, libraries) | County-based outreach, info sessions, referral hubs, SMS campaigns | 60 sessions; 600 inquiries; 420 enrollments | Participants understand options and enroll; 80% show for first class | Steady pipeline across 3 counties | Sustained demand for pathway | 420 enrollments: Pike 45%, Floyd 30%, Letcher 25%; 65% SNAP/TANF; 30% ages 45–64 | CRM sign-ins; monthly dashboard; quarterly review | Outreach Coordinator; Navigators | Partner referrals remain active; transportation barriers addressed | Plain-language, culturally familiar outreach; evening/weekend options; materials in print/SMS
Assessment tools (Northstar); navigators; intake time | Baseline digital assessment; barrier screener; Individual Employment Plans (IEPs) | 380 assessed; 360 IEPs | Clear goals; support plans in place | Progress monitored; barriers resolved earlier | Coaching culture persists | 90% complete assessment+IEP within 2 weeks; 75% with 2+ coach contacts/month | Northstar; CRM; monthly | Navigators; Data & Evaluation Specialist (0.5 FTE) | Adults can schedule assessments within 10 days | Disaggregate by county, age, education; ADA-accessible labs and remote options
Instructors (4); curriculum; labs; learner stipends | 8-week digital literacy bootcamps (basic→intermediate), blended | 24 cohorts; 360 seats; 300 completions | Skill gains; basic digital credential earned | Confidence using email, docs, telehealth, job sites | Community-wide digital inclusion | 80% increase ≥15 pts on Northstar; 70% earn Northstar cert; completion rate ≥75% across all groups | Pre/post tests; attendance; monthly | Lead Instructor; Program Manager | Stable instructor staffing | Cohort times match caregiving/work; track completion gaps and close ≤5%
Device fund; refurb partners; 200 hotspots; ISP partners | Laptop distribution, hotspot lending; ACP/ISP enrollment; online safety mini-course | 300 laptops; 200 hotspots; 360 safety completions | Households online and safer | 240 households maintain service 12+ months | Household digital resilience | 85% device recipients online at 3 mo; 240 sustain at 12 mo | Device logs; ISP confirmations; 3, 6, 12-mo checks | Tech Coordinator; Navigators | ACP/discounts available; cellular coverage adequate | Prioritize no-home-internet households; plain-fee plans; multilingual safety tips as needed
Exam vouchers; instructors; labs | Industry-cert prep (e.g., Google IT Support, CompTIA ITF+/A+, Microsoft, customer service tech, OSHA-10 digital) | 200 start pathways; 160 sit exams | Pass industry exams | Stackable credentials aligned to local roles | Higher wages in digital-involved jobs | 120 earn ≥1 industry cert; pass rates: Google ≥70%, ITF+ ≥65% | LMS, exam vendor reports; monthly | Credential Lead; Instructors | Vendor exam sites accessible | Offer multiple tracks; tutoring; women and 45–64 adults welcomed into IT tracks
Employer engagement lead; stipends | Employer mapping; mock interviews; internships/apprenticeships; hiring events | 20 employers engaged; 80 WBL slots; 200 interviews | Interview readiness and work experience | 120 job placements; 75% 6-mo retention | Local hiring and productivity gains | Median entry wage $16/hr; median wage +$3 within 12 mo; placement by county: Pike 50, Floyd 40, Letcher 30 | Employer MOUs; placement forms; 6/12-mo follow-up; quarterly | Employer Engagement Lead; Navigators | Employer demand remains; background checks clear | Track and address bias; accessible worksites; second-chance-friendly employers
Wraparound fund; partners (childcare, transit, mental health) | Stipends, gas cards, childcare vouchers, benefits navigation | 200 stipends; 150 transport/childcare supports | Attendance and persistence improve | Completion rates rise, fewer stop-outs | Reduced disparities in outcomes | Avg attendance ≥85%; completion gap ≤5% by county/age/education | Attendance; CRM; monthly | Navigators; Program Manager | Supports meet real costs; vendors available | Sliding support based on need; prioritize those balancing work/caregiving
PD budget; QA tools; time | Quarterly PD, peer observations, curriculum refresh, trauma-informed practice | 200 PD hours; 24 observations | Higher instructional quality; 90% satisfaction | Year 2 pass rates +10% vs Year 1 | Strong instructional bench | 4 PD cycles/year; satisfaction ≥90% “good+” | Post-class surveys; QA rubrics; quarterly | Program Manager; Lead Instructor | Staff retention stable | Coaching for new staff; adjust for learning styles
CRM; secure data sharing; dashboards | Build dashboards; monthly data checks; 6/12-mo follow-ups; wage match requests | 24 monthly dashboards; 8 data audits | Timely corrections (attendance, supports) | Continuous improvement embedded | Evidence guides future funding | 80% 6-mo and 12-mo follow-up response; 100% quarterly audits completed | CRM; SMS/phone surveys; UI wage match 2x/yr | Data & Evaluation Specialist | UI data accessible; participants reachable | Consent at intake; multiple contact methods; small incentives for follow-up
MOUs with WIOA, KCTCS, libraries, social services | Credit articulation; shared referrals; joint events; policy voice on affordability | 8 MOUs; 2 articulations; 6 joint events | Seamless referrals; credit for prior learning | Braided funding and seat-sharing | Pathway embedded in regional systems | 25% of grads earn college credit/PLA; 3 co-funded cohorts | MOUs; meeting notes; semiannual | Director of Programs | Partner leadership stable | Ensure rural campuses host cohorts; align schedules across counties

Narrative summary (why this, why now, how we’ll use it)
Eastern Kentucky employers are digitizing front-line and middle-skill work, while many adults 25–64 want better jobs that now require confident use of devices, software, and online tools. This pathway meets that moment: county-based outreach; clear assessments; short, stackable bootcamps; devices and connectivity; credentials mapped to local roles; and work-based learning that leads to real offers. Our equity approach centers convenience and dignity—evening/weekend cohorts, childcare and gas supports, trauma-informed instruction, and disaggregated tracking by county, age, and education so we spot and close gaps fast. We prioritize SNAP/TANF participants and underemployed jobseekers, without deficit framing; we build on their experience and time constraints.

Assumptions include steady employer demand for digital-involved roles, reachable participants for follow-up, and available internet options. Risks include subsidy changes (e.g., ACP), staff turnover, and transportation/childcare shortages. Mitigation: negotiate ISP discounts and maintain hotspot lending; cross-train staff and maintain an instructor bench; pre-budget wraparound supports and partner with local providers. The logic model guides daily operations (who does what, by when), management (monthly dashboards; quarterly reviews), and evaluation (pre/post assessments, credential and wage tracking via UI wage records and employer verification). With a 10-person team and a $900k–$1.1M budget, data collection is “medium”: we use existing systems (CRM, Northstar), short SMS surveys, and twice-yearly wage matches—not burdensome studies. Quarterly reviews drive course corrections; update triggers include staffing shifts, policy changes, and underperforming indicators.

Top assumptions (and mitigation)
- Employer demand stays strong for entry/middle digital roles (maintain quarterly employer roundtables; adjust credential mix).
- Participants can commit 6–10 hrs/week (offer multiple schedules; hybrid options).
- Partners honor MOUs (set quarterly check-ins; shared dashboards).

Top risks/external factors (and mitigation)
- Broadband subsidy changes/ACP sunset (negotiate ISP discounts; expand hotspot pool; advocate via coalition).
- Staff turnover or leave (cross-train; contractor bench; onboarding playbooks).
- Transportation/childcare disruptions (reserve flexible funds; multiple cohort sites per county).

Review cadence and update triggers
- Quarterly learning reviews with partners; monthly internal huddles on dashboard trends.
- Update triggers: staff changes >15% FTE; policy/funding shifts affecting tuition/devices/connectivity; any indicator falling below 80% of target for 2 consecutive months; employer hiring freeze in a priority sector.

Discussion questions
- Do our credential choices match the real jobs and tools used by employers in each county?
- Where are we seeing completion gaps by age or education level, and what’s our near-term fix?
- What wraparound supports had the biggest ROI on attendance—should we rebalance funds?
- Are our follow-up methods reaching alumni evenly across counties?
- Which partnerships should become formal (MOUs/articulation) versus informal referrals?

Note: A logic model is a concise, testable flow from inputs to outcomes with indicators for each step. A theory of change adds the broader causal narrative, context, and evidence base explaining why these links should hold in the real world.

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally strong logic model that demonstrates deep understanding of both the template requirements and nonprofit program design. It successfully balances casual tone with board-appropriate rigor, provides concrete metrics throughout, and shows genuine capacity-awareness for a mid-size organization. The equity integration is particularly strong—disaggregation is woven throughout rather than siloed.
strengths: Outstanding specificity and realism: numeric targets are appropriate for the budget/team size (420 enrollments, 300 completions, 120 certifications), credential choices match regional workforce needs (Google IT Support, CompTIA for Appalachia), and data methods are genuinely feasible for medium capacity (Northstar assessments, CRM tracking, UI wage matches)

Excellent equity integration without deficit framing: disaggregates by county/age/education throughout, includes concrete accommodations (evening/weekend, ADA-accessible labs, plain-language materials), tracks completion gaps with ≤5% target, and names 'second-chance-friendly employers' and trauma-informed practice

Strong if-then logic and outcome progression: clear distinction between outputs (360 seats, 300 laptops) and outcomes (skill gains, job placements, wage increases), testable indicators at each level, and realistic intermediate steps (e.g., 'Interview readiness' → 'Job placements' → 'Wage gains')

Highly practical management tools: monthly dashboards, quarterly reviews, specific update triggers (>15% FTE change, indicators <80% for 2 months), mitigation steps for each assumption/risk, and discussion questions that surface real operational tensions

Appropriate casual tone for board audience: conversational headers ('why this, why now'), plain language ('spot and close gaps fast'), avoids jargon while remaining professional, and uses realistic nonprofit voice ('not burdensome studies')

Comprehensive coverage of all template elements: all 11 table columns populated across 10 rows, 250-350 word narrative (actual ~340), theory of change distinction, assumptions/risks with mitigation, review cadence, discussion questions, and proper header
weaknesses: Minor authenticity concern: while generally excellent, a few phrases feel slightly templated ('durable rural digital-skills pathway,' 'braided funding') though they're sector-appropriate and not egregious

Table formatting challenge: the 11-column table, while complete, would be difficult to read on a single printed page—a real board might need landscape orientation or a simplified visual summary alongside the detailed version

Baseline data assumption: several indicators reference percentage increases or gaps without stating current baseline (e.g., 'Year 2 pass rates +10% vs Year 1' assumes Year 1 data exists), though this is reasonable for a 24-month program

# Rural Digital Skills Pathways — Logic Model Framework

**Prepared by:** Director of Programs  
**Prepared for:** Board of Directors  
**Date:** November 2, 2025  
**Planning Horizon:** 24 months (Jan 2026–Dec 2027)  
**Service Area:** Pike, Floyd, and Letcher Counties, Eastern Kentucky  
**Primary Beneficiaries:** Adults 25–64 with limited digital literacy; underemployed jobseekers; SNAP/TANF participants  
**Team Size:** 10 staff  
**Budget Range:** $900,000–$1,100,000

---

## Logic Model Table

| **Inputs** | **Activities** | **Outputs** | **Short-term Outcomes (6–12 mo)** | **Intermediate Outcomes (1–3 yrs)** | **Long-term Outcomes/Impact (3+ yrs)** | **Indicators & Targets** | **Data Sources & Frequency** | **Responsible Role** | **Assumptions/External Factors** | **Equity Considerations** |
|------------|----------------|-------------|-----------------------------------|-------------------------------------|----------------------------------------|--------------------------|------------------------------|---------------------|----------------------------------|---------------------------|
| **Staffing:** 1 Program Director, 3 Digital Skills Instructors, 2 Career Navigators, 1 Data Coordinator, 1 Outreach Coordinator, 2 Administrative staff | Recruit participants via community partners (libraries, SNAP offices, churches); conduct intake assessments (digital skills baseline, employment status) | 240 adults enrolled across 3 counties (80/county) by Month 6 | 180 participants (75%) complete baseline digital skills assessment showing comfort levels with email, online forms, video calls | 120 participants (50%) report increased confidence using computers for job search, benefits access, telehealth | 90 participants (37.5%) employed in living-wage jobs (≥$15/hr) or advanced to post-secondary training | **Target:** 240 enrolled; 180 complete baseline; disaggregate by county, age (25–39, 40–54, 55–64), education (no HS diploma, HS/GED, some college) | **Source:** Intake forms, pre-assessment surveys; **Frequency:** Monthly enrollment reports | Outreach Coordinator, Data Coordinator | **Assumption:** SNAP/TANF offices will refer clients; **Risk:** Enrollment slower in winter due to weather | Offer evening/weekend sessions; provide childcare stipends; no GED requirement for entry |
| **Funding:** $950K total (wages $520K, participant supports $180K, equipment $120K, facility $80K, eval $50K) | Deliver 8-week foundational courses (2x/week, 3 hrs/session) covering: email setup, online job applications, Zoom basics, password security, benefit portals | 360 course completions (participants may take multiple courses; avg 1.5 courses/person) | 150 participants (62.5%) successfully complete ≥1 online job application independently | 100 participants (42%) gain employment or increase hours/wages within 18 months | 75 participants (31%) sustain employment ≥12 months with benefits (health, paid leave) | **Target:** 360 completions; 150 apply online independently; 100 employed/wage increase; disaggregate by gender, SNAP/TANF status | **Source:** Course attendance logs, post-course skills tests, 6-month follow-up surveys | Instructors, Career Navigators | **Assumption:** Broadband access sufficient at library/hub sites; **Risk:** Employer hiring freezes | Courses in Spanish and English; ASL interpretation available; materials at 6th-grade reading level |
| **Partnerships:** 6 public libraries, 2 community colleges, KY Career Center, SNAP/TANF offices, 4 local employers | Provide 1:1 career navigation (résumé building, interview prep, credential mapping) biweekly for active participants | 600 one-on-one sessions delivered (avg 2.5/participant) | 120 participants (50%) create or update professional résumé and LinkedIn profile | 80 participants (33%) earn industry-recognized credential (MS Office Specialist, Google IT Support, CompTIA) | 60 participants (25%) advance income by ≥$5,000 annually compared to baseline | **Target:** 600 sessions; 120 résumés/profiles; 80 credentials; 60 income gains ≥$5K; track by baseline income quartile | **Source:** Session logs, credential tracking, IRS-authorized income verification at 12 & 24 months | Career Navigators | **Assumption:** Participants will share income data; **Risk:** Credential exam costs may rise | Exam fee waivers funded; flexible scheduling for shift workers; virtual options for homebound caregivers |
| **Equipment:** 30 Chromebooks (loaner program), 15 hotspots, software licenses (Google Workspace, Coursera, Metrix Learning) | Loan Chromebooks + hotspots to participants lacking home internet/devices (up to 6 months) | 90 device/hotspot loans issued (37.5% of participants) | 70 borrowers (78% of borrowers) report using device ≥3x/week for learning or job search | 50 borrowers (56% of borrowers) transition to own device or stable home internet | 40 households (17% of cohort) with sustained broadband subscription (via ACP, subsidized plans, or employment benefit) | **Target:** 90 loans; 70 use ≥3x/week; 50 transition; 40 sustained subscriptions; track ACP enrollment | **Source:** Borrower logs, monthly check-ins, 18-month follow-up survey | Outreach Coordinator, Instructors | **Assumption:** ACP (Affordable Connectivity Program) remains funded; **Risk:** ACP sunset in 2026 | Prioritize rural/unserved areas; partner with ISPs for discounted plans; advocate for policy continuity |
| **Facilities:** Rotating hubs at 6 libraries + 1 mobile lab (converted van) for homebound/childcare-constrained learners | Host employer "meet & greet" sessions (quarterly) connecting participants to hiring managers from healthcare, logistics, remote customer service | 8 employer sessions (4 per year) with 120 total participant attendances | 60 participants (25%) attend ≥1 employer session and submit application to featured employer | 35 participants (15%) hired directly via employer partner referral | 25 hires (10%) retained ≥18 months with upward mobility (promotion, pay raise, or benefits improvement) | **Target:** 8 sessions, 120 attendances; 60 attend + apply; 35 hired; 25 retained ≥18 mo with mobility; disaggregate by employer sector | **Source:** Event sign-ins, application tracking, employer hire reports (MOU-based), retention surveys | Program Director, Career Navigators | **Assumption:** Employers commit to interview participants; **Risk:** Economic downturn reduces hiring | Cultivate 10+ employer partners; diversify sectors; incentivize with free job posting/recruiting support |
| **Data Systems:** Salesforce nonprofit license, Metrix Learning LMS, SurveyMonkey, secure file storage | Conduct quarterly participant satisfaction surveys (anonymous) and semiannual skills assessments (Northstar Digital Literacy) | 720 survey responses (3/participant over 24 mo); 480 skills assessments (2/participant) | Survey avg satisfaction ≥4.2/5; 160 participants (67%) show ≥1 level increase on Northstar scale (8 levels) | Survey avg satisfaction ≥4.5/5; 130 participants (54%) advance ≥2 Northstar levels (e.g., Basic to Intermediate) | 90% of surveyed alumni (n=180, 75% response rate) report continued digital tool use for employment, health, civic engagement | **Target:** ≥85% survey response; satisfaction ≥4.2 then 4.5; 67% then 54% Northstar gains; 90% sustained use; disaggregate by disability status, rural vs. town | **Source:** SurveyMonkey quarterly, Northstar assessments, 24-month alumni survey | Data Coordinator | **Assumption:** Participants comfortable with surveys; **Risk:** Survey fatigue or low literacy barriers | Offer phone/in-person survey option; $10 gift card incentive; plain-language questions; data privacy training for staff |
| **Professional Development:** Annual tech training for staff, trauma-informed care training, equity audits of curricula | Develop peer learning circles (monthly, participant-led) for continued skill practice post-course | 18 peer circles held (avg 12 participants/circle = 216 total attendances) | 80 participants (33%) attend ≥2 peer circles; 60 (25%) report peer circle as "most valuable" program element | 50 participants (21%) take on peer mentor/co-facilitator roles; 40 (17%) enroll in further education (community college, bootcamp) | 30 participants (12.5%) become community digital literacy advocates (e.g., teach neighbors, library volunteers) | **Target:** 18 circles, 216 attendances; 80 attend ≥2; 60 rate most valuable; 50 peer mentors; 40 further ed; 30 advocates; track first-generation college status | **Source:** Attendance logs, satisfaction surveys, mentor applications, college enrollment verification, advocacy activity self-reports | Instructors, Career Navigators | **Assumption:** Participants want peer connection; **Risk:** Circle attendance drops if facilitators leave | Co-design circles with participants; stipend lead mentors $50/session; flexible formats (virtual + in-person) |
| **Community Engagement:** Monthly advisory council (10 members: participants, employers, library staff, college reps) | Collaborate with KY Career Center for job fairs, WIOA co-enrollment, and wrap-around services (transport vouchers, work attire) | 80 participants (33%) co-enrolled in WIOA; 120 receive transport vouchers; 100 receive work attire/supplies | 70 co-enrolled (88% of co-enrolled) access additional WIOA services (training funds, childcare assistance) | 60 co-enrolled (75%) complete WIOA-funded credential on top of digital literacy training | 50 participants (21%) exit poverty threshold (≥200% federal poverty level) at 36 months | **Target:** 80 WIOA co-enrolled; 120 vouchers; 100 attire; 70 access services; 60 dual credentials; 50 exit poverty; disaggregate by single-parent households | **Source:** WIOA enrollment data, voucher logs, attire distribution, income verification, poverty status calc | Career Navigators, Program Director | **Assumption:** WIOA slots available; **Risk:** WIOA policy/funding changes; voucher budget insufficient | Secure MOUs with Career Centers in all 3 counties; build voucher reserve; partner with clothing banks |
| **Marketing/Outreach:** Bilingual flyers, radio spots (local stations), social media, word-of-mouth ambassadors (paid $25/referral) | Host 6 community information sessions (2/county) in Year 1 to explain program, reduce stigma, answer questions | 180 attendees at info sessions (avg 30/session); 120 (67%) enroll within 60 days | Community awareness: 300 adults surveyed post-campaign show 60% recall program name and purpose | Partner orgs (libraries, SNAP offices) report 40% increase in digital literacy referrals year-over-year | Policy impact: County/state officials cite program data in 2 broadband expansion or workforce policy decisions | **Target:** 180 info attendees; 67% convert; 60% awareness; 40% referral increase; 2 policy citations; track reach in Black, Latinx, immigrant communities | **Source:** Event sign-ins, enrollment dates, community awareness survey (n=300, phone/online), partner referral logs, policy documents | Outreach Coordinator | **Assumption:** Stigma reducible; **Risk:** Misinformation about digital skills "too hard" or "not for me" | Use participant testimonials in marketing; host in trusted spaces (churches, food banks); train ambassadors from target communities |
| **Evaluation Budget:** $50K for external evaluator (baseline + midpoint + final reports), data tools, participant incentives | Engage external evaluator to conduct outcome evaluation (pre/post surveys, focus groups, employer interviews) at Months 0, 12, 24 | 3 evaluation reports (baseline, midpoint, final); 6 focus groups (2/county, n=60 participants); 10 employer interviews | Midpoint report identifies 2–3 adjustments (e.g., course timing, childcare needs); staff implement changes by Month 14 | Final report documents ROI: avg participant income gain $6,200; benefit-cost ratio 3:1 (economic + social value) | Findings disseminated in 2 peer-reviewed publications, 3 conference presentations; model replicated in 2 other Appalachian counties | **Target:** 3 reports on time; 60 focus group participants; 10 employer interviews; 2 adjustments; ROI ≥2:1; 2 publications; 3 presentations; 2 replications | **Source:** Evaluator reports, focus group transcripts, employer interview notes, publication tracking, replication inquiries | Data Coordinator, External Evaluator | **Assumption:** Evaluator available; **Risk:** Data quality issues delay analysis | Contract evaluator by Month 1; train staff on data entry; quarterly data audits; build replication toolkit |

---

## Narrative Summary (300 words)

The Rural Digital Skills Pathways program addresses a critical gap in Eastern Kentucky: adults 25–64—especially SNAP/TANF participants and underemployed workers—often lack foundational digital skills required for modern job applications, telehealth, benefits access, and civic participation. In Pike, Floyd, and Letcher Counties, limited broadband infrastructure, lower educational attainment, and economic transition from coal have compounded barriers. This 24-month initiative will serve 240 adults through an 8-week foundational curriculum, 1:1 career navigation, device/hotspot loans, and employer partnerships, ultimately aiming for 37.5% employment in living-wage jobs and 31% sustained employment with benefits.

**Equity Approach:** We reject deficit framing. Participants bring rich community knowledge, resilience, and work ethic; our role is to remove structural barriers—cost, scheduling, childcare, stigma—and co-design learning that honors diverse starting points. We disaggregate data by age, county, gender, education, disability, race/ethnicity, and SNAP/TANF status to surface and address disparities. Courses are offered in English and Spanish, with ASL interpretation, 6th-grade reading materials, and no GED prerequisites. Childcare stipends, evening/weekend sessions, and a mobile lab expand access for caregivers and shift workers. Peer learning circles and paid ambassador roles elevate participant leadership.

**Key Assumptions:**  
1. SNAP/TANF offices and libraries will actively refer clients.  
2. Broadband at hub sites remains reliable; ACP (Affordable Connectivity Program) stays funded.  
3. Employers will interview/hire participants; local economy remains stable.

**Mitigation Steps:**  
1. Cultivate 6+ referral partners; hold monthly coordination meetings.  
2. Secure hotspots; advocate for ACP extension; partner with ISPs for backup plans.  
3. Diversify employer pool (10+ partners across sectors); offer free recruiting support.

The logic model guides implementation via quarterly reviews of indicators, monthly data dashboards, and "update triggers" (staffing turnover, policy shifts, <60% enrollment by Month 6, <40% completion rates). If-then logic ensures each step is testable: *If* we loan devices, *then* participants practice more; *if* they practice, *then* skills improve; *if* skills improve, *then* job applications succeed. External evaluation at Months 12 and 24 validates assumptions and informs course corrections, keeping the model practical for a small team managing real-world complexity.

---

## Logic Model vs. Theory of Change

**Note:** This logic model is a linear, tabular framework showing inputs→activities→outputs→outcomes with measurable indicators, designed for operational management and funder reporting. A theory of change would be a visual flow diagram mapping causal pathways, underlying beliefs, and contextual factors (e.g., "poverty is structural," "peer support drives persistence") across the broader ecosystem—useful for strategic visioning but less granular for day-to-day tracking.

---

## Top 3 Assumptions & Top 3 Risks/External Factors

### **Assumptions**
1. **Referral partnerships will yield steady enrollment:** SNAP/TANF offices, libraries, and churches will proactively refer eligible adults and trust our program.  
   *Mitigation:* Monthly partner check-ins; co-brand materials; share success stories; offer partner staff mini-training on digital equity.

2. **Participants can commit 6 hours/week for 8 weeks:** Despite caregiving, multiple jobs, and transportation challenges, adults will sustain attendance.  
   *Mitigation:* Flexible scheduling (evenings, weekends); childcare stipends ($15/session); transport vouchers; hybrid (some virtual) options; makeup sessions.

3. **Broadband and devices available via ACP, libraries, and loaners:** Connectivity won't be a showstopper for learning or job search.  
   *Mitigation:* 90 loaner devices/hotspots; partnerships with ISPs for discounted plans; mobile lab for homebound learners; offline learning materials as backup.

### **Risks/External Factors**
1. **ACP federal funding sunset (potential 2026):** Loss of $30/month broadband subsidy could strand participants without home internet.  
   *Mitigation:* Advocate for program extension; negotiate ISP discounts; budget reserve for emergency subsidies; prioritize library/hub access.

2. **Economic downturn or employer hiring freeze:** Recession could reduce job openings, undermining employment outcomes despite skill gains.  
   *Mitigation:* Diversify employer partners (healthcare, logistics, remote work less cyclical); pivot to self-employment/gig economy training; emphasize benefit access and civic engagement outcomes.

3. **Staffing turnover (instructors, navigators):** Small nonprofit wages, rural isolation, and burnout may cause key staff to leave mid-cycle.  
   *Mitigation:* Competitive pay (budget $52K avg); professional development stipends; peer support circles for staff; cross-train roles; document curricula for continuity.

---

## Quarterly Review Cadence & Update Triggers

**Quarterly Review Process (Months 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24):**  
- **Data Review:** Program Director and Data Coordinator present dashboard (enrollment, completion, employment, satisfaction by county/demographic).  
- **Staff Debrief:** Instructors and Navigators share qualitative insights (what's working, participant feedback, emerging needs).  
- **Indicator Check:** Compare actuals to targets; flag underperformance (e.g., <60% on any short-term outcome).  
- **Action Items:** Adjust activities (e.g., add Saturday courses, partner with new employer, revise curriculum pacing) within 30 days.  
- **Board Briefing:** Summary memo with 2–3 recommendations; full report biannually.

**Update Triggers (When to Revise Logic Model Mid-Cycle):**  
1. **Enrollment <60% of target by Month 6:** Reassess outreach strategy, eligibility criteria, or referral partnerships.  
2. **Completion rate <50% by Month 9:** Investigate barriers (timing, childcare, content difficulty); pilot solutions.  
3. **Employment outcomes <30% by Month 18:** Expand employer pool, enhance job readiness support, or add credential tracks.  
4. **Staff turnover ≥3 key roles in 6 months:** Revisit compensation, workload, supervision model.  
5. **Policy change (ACP termination, WIOA rule shift, state budget cut):** Convene emergency planning session; adjust budget/activities.  
6. **Equity red flag:** Data show persistent disparity (e.g., no hires among SNAP participants, zero Latinx enrollment): Conduct equity audit, engage affected community, redesign outreach/support.

---

## Discussion Questions for Staff/Partner Alignment

Use these at kickoff retreat, quarterly reviews, or when tensions surface:

1. **Shared Vision:** *When we say "digital literacy," what does success look like for a 45-year-old single mom in Letcher County who's never used email? What would she say changed in her life?*  
   *(Surfaces hidden assumptions about outcomes; centers participant voice; checks if team agrees on "success.")*

2. **Equity Trade-offs:** *If we can only afford childcare stipends OR weekend courses (not both), which better serves our most marginalized participants—and how do we decide?*  
   *(Tests commitment to equity vs. convenience; reveals decision-making values; invites cost-benefit thinking.)*

3. **Theory of Change Assumptions:** *We assume employers will hire participants who complete training. What evidence do we have? What if they don't—does the program still have value?*  
   *(Challenges employment-centric bias; opens space for broader outcomes like civic engagement, health access, family support.)*

4. **Data and Privacy:** *Participants may fear sharing income data or immigration status (even if eligible for services). How do we build trust, and what do we do if 40% refuse to provide follow-up data?*  
   *(Addresses real barriers to evaluation; prompts discussion of consent, anonymization, alternative metrics, and cultural humility.)*

5. **Sustainability and Scale:** *If this works, how do we sustain it after grant funding ends—and should we? Or is our role to prove the model and advocate for public investment?*  
   *(Clarifies organizational mission—service delivery vs. systems change; informs Year 2 fundraising and policy strategy.)*

---

**End of Document**  
*For questions or revisions, contact Director of Programs. Next review: Board meeting 2025-12-15.*

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally comprehensive logic model that fulfills every requirement from the detailed prompt. It demonstrates deep understanding of nonprofit program design, equity-centered evaluation, and the specific context of rural Appalachian workforce development. The casual tone is appropriate for board communication while maintaining professionalism, and the content is immediately actionable for a mid-size organization.
strengths: Extraordinary completeness - addresses every single element of the complex prompt including all 11 table columns, narrative summary, ToC distinction, assumptions/risks with mitigation, quarterly review cadence, update triggers, and discussion questions

Highly realistic and context-appropriate - demonstrates authentic knowledge of rural Appalachia (ACP references, coal transition, county-specific details), SNAP/TANF systems, WIOA co-enrollment, and actual digital literacy assessment tools (Northstar)

Strong equity integration throughout - avoids deficit framing, includes concrete accommodations (ASL, Spanish, 6th-grade materials, childcare stipends, mobile lab), disaggregates data meaningfully, and includes equity audit triggers

Practical and capacity-aware - right-sized for 10-person team with $900K-$1.1M budget, proposes feasible data collection for medium capacity, includes realistic staffing breakdown and budget allocation
Excellent if-then logic chains - clear progression from inputs through long-term outcomes with testable assumptions (e.g., device loans → practice frequency → skill gains → job applications)
Measurable and specific - includes numeric targets throughout (240 enrolled, 75% baseline completion, 37.5% employment), SMART indicators, and appropriate disaggregation by age/county/education
Thoughtful discussion questions - genuinely useful prompts that surface hidden assumptions and values tensions, not just boilerplate
Authentic casual tone - conversational without being unprofessional ('showstopper,' 'real-world complexity'), appropriate for internal board communication
weaknesses: Table formatting complexity - while comprehensive, the 11-column table with 10 detailed rows may be challenging to display on a single printed page as specified; some cells contain 3-4 sentences that would require very small font or landscape orientation
Minor redundancy - some information repeats across narrative summary and assumptions/risks sections (e.g., ACP funding concerns mentioned in both), though this aids comprehension
Ambitious targets - 37.5% employment in living-wage jobs within 24 months is optimistic for this population/region, though not impossible; could benefit from acknowledging this is a stretch goal

Limited discussion of trauma-informed approach - mentions trauma-informed care training in inputs but doesn't elaborate on how this shapes participant interactions, given the likely prevalence of ACEs in the target population

Prepared by Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning Director, for funder, 2025-11-02

## Gulf Coast Resilience Coalition: Resilient Homes Retrofit Initiative – Logic Model Framework

**Program Rationale and Equity Approach:**
The Gulf Coast Resilience Coalition's Resilient Homes Retrofit Initiative directly addresses the disproportionate flood risk faced by Low- and moderate-income (LMI) homeowners and renters, especially older adults and people with disabilities, in flood-prone areas of Harris County, Texas. This initiative is designed to enhance physical and financial resilience against increasingly severe weather events exacerbated by climate change. Our approach is deeply rooted in equity, recognizing that systemic inequities have historically limited access to flood mitigation resources for these vulnerable populations. We employ a proactive, community-centered outreach strategy, utilizing trusted community partners and multilingual materials to ensure no one is left behind. Outreach will specifically target high-risk zip codes with high concentrations of LMI households, older adults, and individuals with disabilities, ensuring culturally and linguistically appropriate engagement. Retrofit solutions will prioritize affordability, accessibility, and resident choice, moving beyond a one-size-fits-all approach. For example, retrofits for older adults might include ADA-compliant ramps alongside flood vents. Data collection will disaggregate by race/ethnicity, zip code, and disability status to continuously monitor equity of access and impact, allowing for adaptive management to address any emergent disparities. Our goal is not merely to "raise awareness," but to equip residents with tangible, accessible, and sustainable solutions that genuinely reduce their vulnerability and improve their quality of life. This logic model will guide implementation by providing clear targets and indicators for each stage, facilitating continuous monitoring and evaluation, and enabling adaptive management to ensure the program remains effective, equitable, and accountable to its beneficiaries and funders. It will serve as the backbone for assessing progress, identifying challenges, and demonstrating impact.

**Distinguishing Logic Model from Theory of Change:**
This Logic Model presents a structured, tabular representation of a linear causal pathway from inputs to long-term outcomes for specific programmatic activities. A Theory of Change, while encompassing similar causal links, typically offers a broader, more narrative explanation of the overall impact pathway, stakeholders, and underlying assumptions, often visually depicted with more complex feedback loops and contextual factors.

---

### Gulf Coast Resilience Coalition: Resilient Homes Retrofit Initiative – Logic Model Framework

(Target: 2) | **STO5:** Programmatic Adjustment: 80% of M&E recommendations integrated into operations. (Target: 80%) | | | | | | | | |

---

**Top 3 Assumptions:**
1.  **Sustained Funding & Political Will:** Availability of federal/state/local grants and continued policy support for flood mitigation efforts for LMI populations.
2.  **Community Trust & Receptiveness:** Target beneficiaries (LMI, older adults, people with disabilities) trust the Coalition and partners, and are willing to participate in and adopt retrofit measures.
3.  **Availability of Skilled Labor:** A sufficient pool of qualified and affordable contractors (including those specialized in accessibility modifications) exists in Harris County to execute retrofits.

**Top 3 Risks/External Factors & Mitigation Steps:**
1.  **Climate Change Intensity:** More severe and frequent flood events than anticipated could overwhelm program capacity and diminish perceived effectiveness.
    *   **Mitigation:** Program design includes a buffer in retrofit capacity; continuously review climate projections to adapt retrofit standards; advocate for regional infrastructure improvements.
2.  **Inflation & Supply Chain Disruptions:** Rising costs of materials and labor, or shortages, could reduce the number of retrofits achievable within budget.
    *   **Mitigation:** Diversify material suppliers where possible; include cost escalation clauses in contractor agreements; actively seek bulk purchasing discounts; explore alternative, cost-effective retrofit materials.
3.  **Beneficiary Turnover & Displacement:** Rapid turnover of residents (especially renters) or displacement due to unaffordability/gentrification in targeted areas could reduce the long-term impact.
    *   **Mitigation:** Prioritize homeowner retrofits where stable residency is more likely; advocate for tenant protections and affordable housing policies in parallel; conduct follow-up surveys to understand reasons for relocation.

**Quarterly Review Cadence & Update Triggers:**
Quarterly reviews with program staff, M&E Director, and leadership to assess progress against targets, identify bottlenecks, and make adaptive adjustments. Update triggers include:
*   Significant staffing shifts (e.g., 20%+ change in FTE).
*   Major policy changes affecting flood resilience or LMI housing.
*   Underperforming indicators (e.g., target achievement below 70% for two consecutive quarters).
*   Major unforeseen external shocks (e.g., catastrophic flood event).
*   Major budget allocation changes (±15%).

**Discussion Questions for Staff/Partners:**
1.  What assumptions in this model feel most critical or potentially shaky from your perspective, and what evidence do we have to support or challenge them?
2.  Are there any populations or specific needs within the LMI, older adult, or disability communities that you feel are not adequately addressed by our current activities or equity considerations?
3.  How can we best leverage our community partners to strengthen our outreach and ensure we are genuinely reaching the most vulnerable individuals who stand to benefit most from this initiative?
4.  Beyond the metrics, what qualitative stories or experiences do we need to capture to fully articulate the impact of this program on residents' lives?

Could strengthen the distinction between homeowner vs. renter outcomes, as these populations face different barriers and the 30% rental unit target may require different logic pathways

Prepared by Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning Director, for funder, Date 2025-11-02

End outcomes/impact (3–5 statements, used to work backward)
- Reduced disaster-related displacement and injury for low- and moderate-income (LMI) households in flood-prone Harris County ZIP codes.
- Lower expected annual flood loss (EAL) and faster housing recovery for program homes and rentals.
- Improved affordability and stability through resilient homes and accessible insurance options.
- Equitable access to resilient retrofits for older adults, people with disabilities, and racially/ethnically diverse communities.
- Stronger local, diverse workforce and policy environment to sustain resilience beyond the grant period.

Logic Model Framework (all indicators disaggregated by race/ethnicity, ZIP code, and disability status; primary beneficiaries: LMI homeowners and renters, especially older adults and people with disabilities)

| Inputs | Activities | Outputs | Short-term Outcomes (6–12 mo) | Intermediate Outcomes (1–3 yrs) | Long-term Outcomes/Impact (3+ yrs) | Indicators & Targets | Data Sources & Frequency | Responsible Role | Assumptions/External Factors | Equity Considerations |

| $1.2M; 8 assessors; tools | Conduct home risk assessments and retrofit designs | 1,000 assessments; 900 written plans | 80% households demonstrate plan comprehension | 70% obtain permits/consent to proceed | Households make risk-reducing investments | 1,000 assessments; 80% knowledge score ≥80%; 70% proceed | Assessment forms (monthly); pre/post quizzes | Construction Manager | Owner access; permit pathways | Prioritize LMI floodplain ZIPs; language access (EN/ES/VI) |

Narrative summary (approx. 300 words)
The Resilient Homes Retrofit Initiative addresses concentrated flood risk among LMI homeowners and renters in Harris County through integrated assessments, construction, tenant-protective rental upgrades, financing supports, and rapid post-event repairs. Grounded in local data, the program prioritizes older adults and people with disabilities living in repeatedly flooded ZIP codes, ensuring language access and accessibility. A dedicated workforce pathway grows diverse local contractor capacity to deliver high-quality, code-compliant retrofits, while policy engagement streamlines permits and aligns incentives. The Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (MEL) system enables timely decisions with geocoded, disaggregated data and quarterly reviews.

The program’s equity approach centers choice, affordability, and non-displacement. Owner retrofits are cost-free to LMI households; rental grants require right-to-return and 5-year affordability. Case management funds accessibility modifications and temporary accommodations. All indicators are disaggregated by race/ethnicity, ZIP code, and disability status and co-governed with a community advisory group. Data collection methods follow high-quality, inclusive, harmonized (HIGH) standards: CRM-based case tracking, mobile QA checklists, HAZUS/GIS modeling, structured surveys with accessible formats, insurance document verification, and event-triggered after-action reviews. A 35-person team and an $8–12M budget focus on feasible volume—1,000 assessments, 700 retrofits (500 owner, 200 rental)—with strong QA and partnerships to manage risk and scale.

Key assumptions include sustained permitting pathways, availability of skilled labor and materials, and stable NFIP/ICC incentives. Risks include major policy or market shifts, severe event access constraints, and landlord participation variability. Mitigation includes MOUs with jurisdictions and VOADs, diversified contracting pools, contingency procurement, and binding tenant protections. The logic model guides implementation by linking resources to measurable changes, aligning roles and timelines, and setting SMART targets for continuous improvement and credible impact evaluation.

How this logic model differs from a theory of change
- A logic model is a visual, testable flow from inputs to outcomes with specific outputs and indicators; it guides day-to-day management and measurement.
- A theory of change narrates broader causal pathways and context, including why strategies should work, often with preconditions and feedback loops beyond the project scope.

Top assumptions (with mitigation)
- Permits/codes allow target retrofits: Mitigate via early policy engagement and pre-approved detail sheets.
- Sufficient contractor capacity: Mitigate via workforce pipeline and multi-year task-order contracts.
- NFIP credits remain available: Mitigate via diversified counseling on private/fair plans and documentation for mitigation discounts.

Top risks/external factors (with mitigation)
- Extreme storms disrupt access: Preposition supplies; post-event MOUs for debris/access; flexible scheduling.
- Supply chain price spikes: Bulk purchase agreements; escalation clauses; alternate approved materials.
- Landlord opt-out risk: Incentive design with higher grants for deeper affordability; enforceable covenants; tenant choice.

Review cadence and update triggers
- Quarterly performance and equity reviews; annual external data audit.
- Triggers: Underperforming indicators for two consecutive quarters; staff turnover >15%; major policy/code change; significant cost variance (>10%); declared disaster or supply chain disruption.

Discussion questions for alignment
- Which ZIP codes and populations should be prioritized first, and why?
- Where are we most likely to face permitting or landlord barriers, and what pre-work is required?
- What is our minimum quality standard per retrofit type, and how will we enforce it equitably?
- Which indicators best signal displacement risk early, and how will we respond?
- How will community advisors shape mid-course corrections?

# LOGIC MODEL FRAMEWORK
## Resilient Homes Retrofit Initiative
**Gulf Coast Resilience Coalition**

**Prepared by:** Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning Director  
**Prepared for:** [Funder Name]  
**Date:** November 2, 2025  
**Program Period:** 60 months (2025–2030)  
**Budget:** $8,000,000–$12,000,000  
**Team Size:** 35 staff  
**Geographic Focus:** Harris County (Greater Houston), Texas  
**Primary Beneficiaries:** Low- and moderate-income homeowners and renters, with priority focus on older adults (65+) and people with disabilities in flood-prone areas

---

## LONG-TERM OUTCOMES/IMPACT (Starting Point – 3 to 5+ Years)

1. **Property Loss Reduction:** 75% of retrofitted homes experience zero flood damage in 100-year flood events, reducing displacement among vulnerable populations by 60% compared to baseline (2020–2024 flood events).

2. **Health & Safety Improvement:** Emergency department visits for flood-related injuries and illnesses decrease 50% among residents of retrofitted homes; heat-related illness incidents decline 40% through improved ventilation systems.

3. **Economic Stability:** Participant households save an average of $3,200 annually in combined flood insurance premiums, utility costs, and disaster recovery expenses; 85% maintain stable housing (no involuntary displacement) over five years.

4. **Community Resilience Capacity:** 500 local contractors trained and certified in resilience retrofitting create 200 sustained jobs; 25 community-based organizations integrate flood resilience into ongoing services, reaching 15,000 additional households with education and preparedness resources.

5. **Policy & Systems Change:** Harris County adopts revised building codes incorporating resilience standards for existing structures; three municipalities implement equitable retrofit subsidy programs modeled on this initiative.

---

## LOGIC MODEL TABLE

|------------|---------------|-------------|--------------------------------------|---------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------|-------------------------|------------------------------|---------------------|--------------------------------|---------------------------|
| **Personnel:** 35 staff (8 outreach coordinators, 12 retrofit technicians, 6 case managers, 4 data/evaluation specialists, 3 finance staff, 2 leadership). **Funding:** $8M–$12M (70% direct services, 15% operations, 10% evaluation, 5% contingency). **Partnerships:** 18 community-based organizations, 40 licensed contractors, County Office of Emergency Management, Regional disability service agencies. **Infrastructure:** Office space, 6 vehicles, inspection equipment, CRM database. | **Year 1–5:** Conduct multilingual outreach at senior centers, faith communities, disability service sites, public housing facilities. 3 municipalities adopt subsidy programs modeled on this initiative. | **Target:** 3,000 assessments; 4,800 session attendees; 70% knowledge gain; 1,200 applications. **Disaggregate by:** Race/ethnicity (Asian, Black, Latinx, White, Other), household type (senior, disability, family), zip code, homeowner/renter, FEMA flood zone. | **Household intake database:** Monthly exports. **Pre/post knowledge tests:** After each session. **Case notes:** Weekly CRM updates. **Attendance logs:** Per event. | **Outreach Coordinators** (lead). **Case Managers** (enrollment). **M&E Specialists** (data quality audits). | **Assumption 1:** Households prioritize flood risk despite competing urgent needs (housing instability, medical costs). **External Factor 1:** Major flood event increases demand beyond capacity. **Mitigation:** Maintain waitlist; activate volunteer surge capacity; secure bridge funding. | **Language Access:** All materials in English, Spanish, Vietnamese; ASL interpreters at all sessions. **Digital Divide:** Paper-based options for all processes; ## NARRATIVE SUMMARY (280 words)

Harris County residents face escalating flood risk from intensifying storms and aging infrastructure, with low- and moderate-income households, older adults, and people with disabilities experiencing disproportionate harm due to historic disinvestment, inaccessible emergency systems, and inability to afford property hardening. The Resilient Homes Retrofit Initiative addresses these intersecting inequities through a comprehensive approach: subsidizing structural retrofits for 900 homes, building local resilience workforce capacity through training 400 residents, and advancing policy change to institutionalize equitable flood protection.

Our equity approach rejects deficit narratives, instead recognizing that flood vulnerability results from systemic failures—redlining, exclusionary zoning, inadequate public investment—not individual shortcomings. We center community leadership through resident advisors who shape program design, prioritize accessibility (linguistic, physical, digital), and embed protections against displacement (renter lease guarantees, preference points for marginalized groups). Disaggregated data collection by race, disability status, and geography ensures we track whether benefits reach those most impacted and course-correct when disparities emerge.

**Key assumptions:** (1) Households will prioritize flood resilience despite competing crises if we reduce barriers (cost, complexity, time); (2) Landlords will participate with sufficient incentives and tenant protections; (3) Quality workforce training creates pathways to stable employment even for residents facing employment discrimination. **Top risks:** (1) Major flood overwhelms capacity—mitigated via waitlist protocols and surge volunteer activation; (2) Material cost inflation exceeds budget—mitigated via bulk purchasing and contingency reserve; (3) Political shifts undermine policy advocacy—mitigated via bipartisan framing and career staff relationships.

This logic model guides implementation through quarterly reviews assessing if-then linkages (e.g., *if* 70% gain knowledge, *then* 40% should apply for retrofits; if lower, investigate barriers). Update triggers include: <30% application conversion, staff turnover >20%, policy windows opening, funding shifts, or underperformance on equity indicators (e.g., <35% participation from redlined areas). The model prioritizes feasible data collection—leveraging existing databases, brief surveys, administrative records—appropriate for a 35-person team managing rigorous evaluation within operational realities.

---

## LOGIC MODEL VS. THEORY OF CHANGE

This **logic model** presents a linear, tabular display of programmatic inputs, activities, outputs, and outcomes with specific indicators and targets, emphasizing measurable program management and accountability. A **theory of change** would provide a broader visual narrative mapping causal pathways, underlying assumptions, contextual preconditions, and spheres of influence/control, often including multiple strategies and external actors beyond direct program control, designed to articulate *why* and *how* change happens rather than *what* the program delivers.

---

## TOP ASSUMPTIONS, RISKS, AND MITIGATION

### **Top 3 Assumptions**
1. **Household Prioritization:** Low-income households will engage with flood resilience retrofitting despite competing urgent needs (rent, food, healthcare) *if* we eliminate cost barriers, simplify processes, and provide wraparound case management.
   - **Test:** Track application rates among assessed households; if <35%, conduct barrier analysis interviews.

2. **Landlord Participation:** Property owners will retrofit renter-occupied units *if* subsidies cover 100% of costs and lease protections prevent retaliatory rent increases or evictions.
   - **Test:** Monitor landlord participation rates; target 35% of retrofits in renter units; if <25% by Year 2, adjust incentives or shift to whole-building strategies.

3. **Workforce Absorption:** Local contractors and employers will hire training graduates despite limited prior experience *if* certifications validate skills and program provides hiring support.
   - **Test:** Track 6-month employment rates; if <60%, intensify employer engagement and consider transitional employment partnerships.

### **Top 3 External Risks & Mitigation**
1. **Major Flood Event Overwhelms Demand:** Hurricane or severe flooding creates surge of 5,000+ requests beyond capacity.
   - **Mitigation:** Maintain prioritized waitlist with transparent criteria; activate volunteer "resilience brigades" for rapid minor repairs; secure pre-approved bridge funding ($500K line of credit); coordinate with County Emergency Operations Center for resource sharing.

2. **Supply Chain Disruption / Cost Inflation:** Material costs increase >30%, reducing number of affordable retrofits.
   - **Mitigation:** Establish bulk purchasing agreements with three regional suppliers; build 5% cost contingency into retrofit budget ($400K); allow flexible material specifications (equivalent performance standards); phase installations to capitalize on price fluctuations.

3. **Political Opposition / Policy Gridlock:** County/municipal leadership changes result in opposition to building code revisions or subsidy programs.
   - **Mitigation:** Cultivate bipartisan champions (frame as fiscal responsibility and job creation, not just climate/equity); build relationships with career staff in planning/emergency management who persist across administrations; document cost-benefit analyses showing public savings; maintain diverse coalition including business and insurance industry allies.

---

## QUARTERLY REVIEW CADENCE & UPDATE TRIGGERS

**Quarterly Review Process:**
- **Participants:** Full staff (35), Board Resilience Committee (5 members), 3 community advisors, 2 funder representatives (optional).
- **Agenda:** (1) Review output and outcome data against targets; (2) Analyze equity indicators for disparities; (3) Assess assumptions (are if-then links holding?); (4) Identify implementation challenges and adaptations; (5) Update risk register; (6) Adjust work plans for next quarter.
- **Deliverable:** 5-page dashboard with stoplight indicators (green/yellow/red) and narrative explaining variances, shared with all stakeholders within 2 weeks.

**Update Triggers (Immediate Logic Model Revision Required):**
1. **Underperformance on Equity Indicators:** <35% participation from historically redlined neighborhoods, <20% participation from people with disabilities, or significant disparities in satisfaction/outcomes by race/ethnicity for two consecutive quarters.
2. **Staffing Changes:** Turnover >20% in single quarter, loss of key leadership (Executive Director, M&E Director, Policy Director), or funding reduction requiring >15% staff cuts.
3. **Policy Windows or Shifts:** Unexpected policy opportunity (e.g., state/federal funding becomes available, county leadership change creates opening) or adverse policy change (e.g., budget cuts to emergency management, restrictions on subsidy programs).
4. **Major External Event:** Hurricane, severe flooding, or other disaster significantly alters context, demand, or capacity.
5. **Significant Variance from Logic:** Application rate <25% of assessments, job placement rate <50%, or retrofit completion <120/year for two consecutive quarters, indicating broken if-then assumptions requiring theory revision.
